newsitem.title: UK: Palladium hits the highest price this decade.
newsitem.headline: Palladium hits the highest price this decade.

text.p: Palladium soared to its highest price of the 1990s in London on Tuesday as lack of material forced buyers to pay more for the rare white metal.
Palladium fixed at $179.75 per ounce, its strongest fixing since $181.50 recorded on April 14, 1989.
Tuesday morning had seen it at $177.50, its highest in more than five years. On January 2 this year it was valued at $120.75 and even that was the highest since late September 1996.
"It's to do with (Russian) non-delivery, Tokyo (futures market) positions and fund interest all happening together," a dealer said.
The surge also coincides with London's Platinum Week when producers, users and dealers in platinum, palladium and their lesser sister metals gather for meetings and socialising.

Market liquidity has tightened all year as administrative problems delayed exports from Russia, the leading producer. About half of Russia's exports come from ever diminishing government stockpiles. Their size is a tightly held secret.
Russia accounts for around 67 percent of world supply of the metal which is used mainly in autocatalysts for cleaning up car exhaust gases, in electronics and for dental alloys.
Shipments could begin late June, Russian officials said.
But that has done nothing to alleviate the dearth of currently available material.
Borrowing rates have soared to around 26 per cent for a month, from a more normal two percent.
"At that rate it is too expensive just to borrow for a couple of days so you have to buy which tightens the liquidity even more," a senior dealer said.
It has also introduced potential price volatility. "I would not be surprised to see palladium $20 higher or lower than it is now within a few days," one dealer said.
In 1980 when gold and silver prices were rocketing to record levels, palladium hit its historic peak at around $270.00.

Palladium was last at current levels in 1989 when reports suggested that a "cold fusion" process could use the metal as a catalyst to produce apparently limitless energy. Supplies from the second largest producer South Africa were also disrupted.
"These were exceptional times, much more so than now," commented one long-serving market analyst.
Gold edged up 50 cents on Tuesday to $343.00, silver was at $4.72/$4.74 up eight cents and platinum was $7.25 firmer at $396.50/$397.50.-Brian Spoors London Newsroom +44 171 542 8058
